Following the second chorus, we break into a guitar solo from Brian May. Brian solo’s over the ♭VII of B Mixolydian. Along with the rocking and rumbling piano lines from Freddie Mercury, the solo features lots of double stops in the vein of Chuck Berry. After the solo, we break into a short bridge, and into the third verse.

Part 1
The song starts with 1/8 pulsing guitar power chords exposing the opening tonic of D. Freddie Mercury enters with the vocals that are heavily delayed and start on the upbeat that ends on the 1/8 preceding the opening downbeat of the related harmonic phrase. Each vocal delay extends the first. Note that the “around around around…” words all fall off-beat despite they first sound deceptively on-beat. The harmony combines the D major chord created by the echoed lead vocal and the guitar power chords with the descending bass line.

Part 2
We then explode into a second section of the intro that prepares the modulation to E Major. The melodic phrasing is interesting: The shouted upbeat ends just before the opening downbeat and lyrical-wise it remains unresolved. The tension is supported by the sus4 dissonances and the step-up modulation. Additional varispeed guitar screams are echoed, similarly to the intro vocals, as heavily harmonized vocals enter, just before the main riff enters.
As the song fades out, the band quotes the Chuck Berry classic “Little Queenie”.

Down in the city just Hoople and me
 Don’t I love him so?

This is a reference to the band, Mott the Hoople, which for quite some time was an associated act on Queen tours. Members of both Queen and Mott the Hoople were incredibly good friends, and sometimes were known to play songs together backstage for fun.
Your matches still light up the sky

This is completely a reference to two things. First it’s a reference to the use of lighters during slow songs and solos at rock concerts.



The second thing is a reference to an old school practice of lighting matches and throwing them into a pool or onto the ground while you are supposedly waiting for a loved one to return.
